            $body.addClass('mobile');
        } else {
            window.mobile = false;
            window.desktop = true;
            $body.removeClass('mobile');
            $body.addClass('desktop');
        }
    }

    let media = window.matchMedia('(max-width: 800px)');
    media.addEventListener('change', changed_mobile);
    changed_mobile(media);
</script>

<script>
    $(function() {
        let $mobile_header = $('.mobile-header');
        let $burger = $('.mobile-header .burger');
        let $menu_overlay = $('.mobile-header .menu-overlay');
        let $return = $('.mobile-header .return');

        let active = false;
        let level = 0;
        let $menu_root = $('.mobile-header .menu-root');

        let overlay_height = window.innerHeight - $('.mobile-header .top')[0].scrollHeight
            - $('.mobile-header .menu-bar')[0].scrollHeight;
        $('.mobile-header .menu-overlay').css({'height': overlay_height});

        $burger.on('click', function() {
            if (active) {
                active = false;
                $menu_overlay.fadeOut(200);
                $return.css({'opacity': 0});
                $mobile_header.css({'background-color': '#212E3B'});
                $burger.removeClass('active');
                $('body').css({'overflow': 'inherit'});
            } else {
                active = true;
                $menu_overlay.fadeIn(200);
                $return.css({'opacity': 1});
                $mobile_header.css({'background-color': '#121F29'});
                $burger.addClass('active');
                $('body').css({'overflow': 'hidden'});
            }
        });
        
        $return.on('click', function () {
            if (level < 1) return;

            $menu_root.find('> li > ul '.repeat(level)).removeClass('menu-active');
            level -= 1;
            $menu_root.css({'transform': 'translateX(' + (-level * 100) + 'vw)'});
            
            if (level === 0) {
                $return.css({'display': 'none'});
            }
        });
    
        $menu_root.on('click', function (event) {
            let $target = $(event.target);
            if ($target.hasClass('menu-button')) {
                level += 1;
                $menu_root.find('> li > ul '.repeat(level)).removeClass('menu-active');
                $target.children('ul').first().addClass('menu-active');
                $menu_root.css({'transform': 'translateX(' + (-level * 100) + 'vw)'});
                $return.css({'display': 'flex'});
            }
        });
        
        let last_scroll = window.scrollY, top = 0, max = $mobile_header.outerHeight();
        $(window).on('scroll', function() {
            top += last_scroll - window.scrollY;

            if (top < -max) top = -max;
            if (top > 0) top = 0;

            $mobile_header.css({'top': top + 'px'});
            last_scroll = window.scrollY;
        });
    });
</script>

<script>
    $(function() {
        let open = false;
        let active = null;
        let closeTimer = null;
        
        $('.desktop-header .menu-root .menu-button').on('mouseover', function() {
            let new_active = $(this).data('menu');
            
            if (active && active !== new_active) {
                $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active).css({'display': 'none'});
                $('.desktop-header .menu-button').removeClass('active');
            }
            
            $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + new_active).css({'display': 'inherit'});
            $(this).addClass('active');
            active = new_active;
            
            let height = $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active)[0].scrollHeight + 'px';
            $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': height});
            
            if (!open) {
                open = true;
                $('.desktop-header').addClass('active');
                $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'display': 'inherit'});
                
                if (height === '0px') {
                    height = $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active)[0].scrollHeight + 'px';
                    $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': height});
                }
            }
        });
        
        $('.desktop-header').on('mouseover', function() {
           clearTimeout(closeTimer);
        });
        
        $('.desktop-header').on('mouseout', function() {
            if (open) {
                closeTimer = setTimeout(function() {
                    $('.desktop-header').removeClass('active');
                    $('.desktop-header .menu-button').removeClass('active');
                    
                    $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': '0'});

                    let _active = active;
                    setTimeout(function() {
                        $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + _active).css({'display': 'none'});
                    }, 250);
                    
                    active = null;
                    open = false;
                }, 400);
            }
        });
    });
</script>

                                <div class="s-p-co-l">
								    <h2>Intro</h2>
<p>Dridex mostly comes to us as spam which contains a .doc with some macros, responsible for downloading a dropper. One can quickly analyze it using oledump.py and looking through vbscript, or naturally, just try to run it in a sandbox and obtain the dropped files.<br />
<span id="more-12229"></span></p>
<h2>CFG extraction</h2>
<p>After unpacking the rather mundane packer, lets get into the juicy parts. We are presented with a small stage1 dropper, which looks rather basic.<br />
The purpose of the dropper is to download the main binary from C&amp;C and inject it to explorer, plus some generic initialization stuff.<br />
First lets take a look how to find C&amp;C addresses. In older samples there was a PE section called .sdata and it contained xored xml-document with all of the interesting data,</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text default"><div class="text codecolorer">&amp;lt;config botnet=&quot;301&quot;&amp;gt;<br />
&amp;lt;server_list&amp;gt;<br />
85.25.238.9:8843<br />
91.142.221.195:5445<br />
46.37.1.88:473<br />
&amp;lt;/server_list&amp;gt;<br />
&amp;lt;/config&amp;gt;</div></div>
<p>About a week ago that changed. There is no more .sdata â data sits in plain sight somewhere in memory, structured as follows:</p>
<div id="gist28088764" class="gist"></div>
<div id="gist28088764" class="gist"></div>
<table class="highlight tab-size js-file-line-container" data-tab-size="8">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC1" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">struct</span> <span class="pl-c1">cfg_t</span> {</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC2" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">int</span> field_0;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC3" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">unsigned</span> __int16 botnet;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC4" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">unsigned</span> __int8 count;</td>
</tr>
<tr>

</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC6" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ip_addr cnc[count];</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC7" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">};</td>
</tr>
<tr>

</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC9" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">struct</span> ip_addr {</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC10" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">char</span> ipaddr[<span class="pl-c1">4</span>];</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-cfg_struct-h-LC11" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">__int16 port;</td>

</table>
<table class="highlight tab-size js-file-line-container" data-tab-size="8">
<tbody>
<tr>

</tbody>
</table>
<div class="gist-meta"><a href="https://gist.github.com/mak/894eaa9a6fc5df0aee88/raw/0cedbd0328782f044c64234ad9268fba17760ac4/cfg_struct.h">view raw</a> <a href="https://gist.github.com/mak/894eaa9a6fc5df0aee88#file-cfg_struct-h">cfg_struct.h</a> hosted with â¤ by <a href="https://github.com">GitHub</a></div>
<p>Using a yara signature like this:</p>
<pre>  $new_get_cnc = { E8 [4] BE [4] 8D ?? 5B 83 C4 1C 0F [3] 08 0F [3] 09 0F [3] 0A 0F [3] 0B 0F [3] 0C }
</pre>
<p>we can easily locate address where it is used and pull out that data.</p>
<h3>First encounter with C&amp;C</h3>
<p>Ok, now we have to find code that calls those addresses. After going back-and-forth between references we stumble across this function:</p>
<p><img loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11999" src="../../../../uploads/2015/11/dridgetcnc-1.png" alt="dridgetcnc" width="536" height="515" /></p>
<p>Here is a little digression, if you donât know this already: Dridex uses encoded strings and a run-time api resolving to make our life harder. Fortunately nothing fancy, a simple xor:</p>
<div id="gist28088388" class="gist"></div>
<div id="gist28088388" class="gist"></div>
<table class="highlight tab-size js-file-line-container" data-tab-size="8">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC1" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC2" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">def</span> <span class="pl-en">dridex_decode_name</span>(<span class="pl-smi">addr</span>,<span class="pl-smi">idx</span>,<span class="pl-smi">delm</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&#8220;</span><span class="pl-cce">\x00</span><span class="pl-pds">&#8220;</span></span>):</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC3" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">addr <span class="pl-k">+=</span> <span class="pl-c1">8</span>; tmp <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&#8216;</span><span class="pl-pds">&#8216;</span></span>; j <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC4" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">xkey <span class="pl-k">=</span> GetManyBytes(addr,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC5" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">for</span> i <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-c1">range</span>(idx<span class="pl-k">+</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>):</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC6" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">tmp <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&#8216;</span><span class="pl-pds">&#8216;</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC7" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">while</span> <span class="pl-k">not</span> tmp.endswith(delm):</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC8" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">tmp <span class="pl-k">+=</span> <span class="pl-c1">chr</span>(<span class="pl-c1">ord</span>(xkey[j<span class="pl-k">%</span><span class="pl-c1">8</span>]) <span class="pl-k">^</span> Byte(addr<span class="pl-k">+</span><span class="pl-c1">8</span><span class="pl-k">+</span>j))</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC9" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">j<span class="pl-k">+=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<table class="highlight tab-size js-file-line-container" data-tab-size="8">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td id="file-dridex_decode-py-LC10" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-k">return</span> tmp.strip(delm)</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<div class="gist-meta"><a href="https://gist.github.com/mak/dccb5f579a3d1e0b0180/raw/8d157a3a8bf0c1e49423631454837e57a562cfa9/dridex_decode.py">view raw</a> <a href="https://gist.github.com/mak/dccb5f579a3d1e0b0180#file-dridex_decode-py">dridex_decode.py</a> hosted with â¤ by <a href="https://github.com">GitHub</a></div>
<p>Back to business. Despite whatâs often reported, the first communication is not encrypted with xor as described in other articles, but with RC4. Keys are stored somewhere in binary encoded as any other string. They are different per botnet but otherwise donât seem to change that often. For botnet 220 the key is:</p>
<pre>ub9sKhcvsePZXuFC4HRw8KjFSIVUxsdAJXFyVP3Acl7HYL9KQBzETBzFvk2FlxeHZFBljIPps21W
</pre>
<p>Armed with C&amp;C addresses and key, we can create a message. Fortunately, the Dridex authors were kind enough not to use any fancy binary format, just plain xml (sometimes gziped but we got to that part laterâ¦) and the message looks something like this:</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text geshi">
<div class="text codecolorer">&lt;loader&gt;<br />
&lt;get_module unique=&#8221;%s&#8221; botnet=&#8221;%d&#8221; system=&#8221;23128&#8243; name=&#8221;%s&#8221; bit=&#8221;32&#8243;/&gt;<br />
&lt;soft&gt;&lt;![CDATA[]]&gt;&lt;/soft&gt;<br />
&lt;/loader&gt;</div>
</div>
<p>where âuniqueâ is a bot name, created as follows:</p>
<p><img loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-12000" src="../../../../uploads/2015/11/driduniqe-1.png" alt="driduniqe" width="560" height="339" /></p>
<p>âbotnetâ is a 2 bytes value hidden in config, and the name corresponds to a request weâd like to do.</p>
<p>The most basic request is `list` which obtains a list of nodes.</p>
<p>After decrypting the response, using RC4 with the same key, we got something like this, base64-encoded string is copied without decoding and dealt with in the next stage.</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text geshi">
<div class="text codecolorer">&lt;root&gt;<br />
&lt;module name=&#8221;list&#8221;&gt;<br />
Apts4+yozUR8Nbcan9dOya6yFIq6mxfdnJjlydF+uAELwWrIEIcvQIkk1mPURXr25/IwtnDW9l4s36C1<br />
0iL0O6H3sJ1xhnUvcLN7ccjZU+RNySaj6YYSALvTBcGfNreUusy1ESLHKscAq4LJqzNy3UoB6fHLyJkU<br />
LKhVFpKnogyKQEt4lctDeIpAS3iKQwb3205JWYYEZMwTJQEzS9B29XQK6aa1VsPxFd31tsa7IPRFldSb<br />
dDgUVQmVq35rDX5nJNAfOYttztqNC8etW0oDIxrkEzMJedOrGIIvAnMUtdjDeIouPdceNNhiLzkGY3q6<br />
gQoV8pwkCQsSrwltmFOmbyW9l6Vx+XWBiD8wOROQS3iK<br />
&lt;/module&gt;<br />
&lt;root&gt;</div>
</div>
<p>The next command is `bot` and is responsible for downloading main dll</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text geshi">
<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="line-numbers">
<div>1</div>
</td>
<td>
<div class="text codecolorer">&lt;root&gt;&lt;module name=&#8221;bot&#8221;&gt;base64-string&lt;/module&gt;&lt;/root&gt;</div>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
<p>There is no rocket science here, base64-encoded string is being decoded and loaded into memory, what is interesting in this case is how it is done.</p>
<h3>Loader</h3>
<p>It is normal in the malware world to apply an extra layer of protection to files stored in the local system. For example Tinba additionally xors itâs configuration file with bot id. But a non-written rule of how most malware works, is that every code is passed through memory in clear text. As one can guess this not the case here.</p>
<p>Indeed, Dridexâes method of injecting into another process is quite nice. It consists of two stub loaders. The first is responsible of decoding real payload (again just xor), while the second is used as a simple pe-loader which makes it possible to run PE files without syscalls like LoadLibrary or CreateProcess.</p>
<p><img loading="lazy" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-12001" src="../../../../uploads/2015/11/dridprepl-1.png" alt="dridprepl" width="595" height="266" /></p>
<p>This is clearly visible in any memory tracer,</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text geshi">
<div class="text codecolorer">[37ceca4ac82d0ade9bac811217590ecd.bin &#8211; 3980][3952]called[pre] NtOpenProcess(1212) = 1276 &#8211; C:\WINDOWS\Explorer.EXE<br />
&#8230;<br />
[37ceca4ac82d0ade9bac811217590ecd.bin &#8211; 3980][3952]called[pre] NtWriteVirtualMemory(Explorer.EXE,1fe0000,459264) src: 932e90<br />
&#8230;<br />
[37ceca4ac82d0ade9bac811217590ecd.bin &#8211; 3980][3952]called[pre] NtWriteVirtualMemory(Explorer.EXE,b20000,2552) src: 12f348<br />
&#8230;<br />
[37ceca4ac82d0ade9bac811217590ecd.bin &#8211; 3980][3952]called[pre] NtWriteVirtualMemory(Explorer.EXE,b209f8,2460) sr c: 415020<br />
&#8230;<br />
[37ceca4ac82d0ade9bac811217590ecd.bin &#8211; 3980][3952]called[post] NtAllocateVirtualMemoryx(SELF,1900000,12288,MEM_COMMIT|MEM_RESERVE, RWX &#8212; )<br />
[37ceca4ac82d0ade9bac811217590ecd.bin &#8211; 3980][3952]called[post] NtAllocateVirtualMemoryx(SELF,1910000,65536,MEM_COMMIT, RW- &#8212; )</div>
</div>
<p>What is important with further analysis is that it relays quite heavily on loader metadata, which is somehow modeled to resemble a legit PE â which obviously it is not, as it missed almost every PE characteristic besides the typical MZ-PE signature.</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text geshi">
<div class="text codecolorer">0000000: 4d5a 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â MZ&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;..<br />
0000010: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;.<br />
0000020: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;.<br />
0000030: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 4000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;@&#8230;<br />
0000040: 5045 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â PE&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;..<br />
0000050: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;.<br />
0000060: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;.<br />
0000070: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;.<br />
0000080: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;.<br />
0000090: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;.<br />
00000a0: 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 Â &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;.</div>
</div>
<p>Main dll is obviously packed â however I leave that challenge to the reader as a homework, as this is the end of introduction. Cya in the next part!<br />
mak</p>
